prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AlO & TiO/TiO2 in VY CMa, band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Scince Goal aims to resolve emission of unblended lines of AlO, TiO, and multiple lines of TiO2 in VY CMa in band 7 at a resolution of ~0.1". The extended configuration of the array is absolutely necessary to resolve the source (see Science Justification). Although lines of much more extended emission (>>1.0") of other species will be covered by this correlator setup, those species are beyond our science scope. A secondary goal is to detect lines of isotopologues of the two oxides in velocity- and source-integrated maps. All lines will be used in an excitation analysis and two of our SGs with VY CMa as the target are prepared to cover lines in possibly broadest range of Eu.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The spectral range proposed here was covered in our survey of VY CMa with SMA (Kaminski et al. 2013). Based on this data, the typical peak flux densities and line widths of TiO2 are F~200 mJy and FWHM~50 km/s, while the size of the TiO2 emission is FWHM=0.4" and smaller for TiO.
The peak flux of 200 mJy for a source of 0.4" is expected to have a peak flux of 8 mJy when resolved with a 0.08" beam of ALMA. To detect the peaks of the TiO2 lines at a 5-sigma level, we request observations with rms of 1.6 mJy. Using the OT, we calculate this can be achieved in 3.4 h of total time including all calibrations and overheads.
At this sensitivity, the S/N for profile-integrated emission of TiO2 and TiO is then ~30 allowing to detect the 10 times weaker isotopologues at 3-sigma level. After integration of the signal over the entire source, the statistical significance will be ~25 times better and even the 14 times weaker isotopologues of TiO and TiO2 can be well identified.
VY CMa's continuum is strong and even after being resolved will produce sufficient S/N for our studies. The peak flux in our SMA observations at 350 GHz, which did not resolve the source, was 0.65 Jy. Our SMA observation indicate the continuum source size of 0.3"x0.5", giving peak flux of 43 mJy per 0.08" beam with ALMA.

This Scince Goal aims to resolve emission of unblended lines of AlO, TiO, and multiple lines of TiO2. With all the four bassbands set to the width of 1875 MHz and using channel spacing of 976.563 kHz we can cover almost fully both receiver bands (LSB & USB) and get access to a large number of TiO2 transitions. The setup was optimised to cover these lines and max number of their isotopologues. Maximum possible bandwidth is required. Owing to very complex nature of the ourflow of VY CMa, the line profiles have substructure with components as narrow as 3 km/s, fully justifung the requested spectral resolution. The setup covers also a line of AlO which has a hyperfine structure, which we would like to partially resolve.

This SG aims to resolve emission of multiple unblended lines of AlO, TiO, and TiO2. From SMA and ALMA SV observations it is known that the emission regions are smaller than FWHM~0.4 arcsec (TiO2, See Fig. 2 in Sci. Just.). Extended configuration of the array with an angular resolution of ~0.1" is therefore absolutely necessary to resolve the source, especially in TiO (see Science Justification). Although lines of much more extended emission (>>1.0") of other species will be covered by this correlator setup, we do not request a compact configuration, as those species are beyond our science scope. Also, the largest scales of the TiO2 emission reach 1" (see Fig. 2 in Sci. Just.) so higher angular resolutions are not desired here. The C36-6 configuration of Cycle 3 is the most optimal one.

Although the full profiless are relatively broad in VY CMa, they contain substructure which can be resolved only at the resolution of 1.6 km/s or better. The current value is already a compromise after spectral smoothing. The data rate 12.21 MB/s only slighty exceeds the limit of 12 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AlO & TiO map of Mira, band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral setup for Mira in band 7 aiming to resolve emission in a single line of AlO and of TiO. Single pointing.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our APEX observations indicate that the lines of TiO and AlO, which are the primary objective of this SG, have similar peak flux densities of 144 mJy. While the line of TiO has a width typical for this source (FWHM=7.5 km/s), the AlO line is broadened by hyperfine structure resulting in FWHM~10 km/s.
The size of the emission regions is unknown, except it should be larger than 0.2" (optical emission) and smaller than 0.6" (distance to the companion, see Scientific Justification). Assuming the source size of 0.3", which is a geometric mean of the two limits and is rather a conservative figure (as the ring-like source is likely to fill a smaller solid angle), we calculate that the resolved emission should have peak flux density of 10 mJy per 0.08" beam. To detect the peaks at a 5-sigma level, we request rms of 2.0 mJy. Using the OT, we calculate that this rms can be achieved in 4 h (including all calibrations and overheads). At the requested sensitivity, the S/N corresponding to profile-integrated flux of TiO is ~14 and slightly better for the broader feature of AlO.
The peak continuum flux of Mira measured with APEX/LABOCA at 345 GHz is 340 mJy and the source is not resolved by APEX. Although the size of the source of the submillimeter continuum is unknown, based on the optical and NIR observations, we assume it may be as large as 0.2" (recently confimed by the ALMA SV data). Then the flux densities of 85 mJy per 0.1" beam are expected giving S/N of >2000. The continuum is strong enough to produce sufficient S/N for our studies even when the continuum source is more extended than we assumed.

This setup covers the strongest line of AlO available in band 7, i.e. N=9-8. The only *unblended* transition of TiO that can be observed simultaneously with this line of AlO is the J=11-10 line at Omega=3 at 355.6 GHz (Eu=386 K) and the corresponding line of the isotopologue 46TiO. The lines of AlO and TiO+46TiO will be covered by two separate baseband. Additionally, one spectral unit covers a few lines of TiO2 which may be detected at the requested sensitivity, and one unit covers the CO J=3-2 v=1 line, which will be used to investigate fluorescence effects in the inner wind. To cover all those lines, we need the full bandwidth of the correlator.
At the same time we request nearly the highest resolution as some of these lines (e.g. CO v=1) are expected to have FWHM of a few km/s. At this resolution, the gas kineamtics can still be studied in deep detail in this source.

The lines in Mira are very narrow (<10 km/s) and high spectral resolution is necessary to study the lines. The current value is already a compromise after spectral smoothing. The data rate 12.21 MB/s only slighty exceeds the limit of 12 MB/s.

As explained in Sci. Just. (Fig. 3), we aim to resolve TiO emission regions of the size of 0.2" and therefore request for a high angular resolution (~0.08"). The AlO emision may be more extended, even 0.6" (also the distance to the companion). We choose the configuration C36-6 (or similar) as the most optimal for this SG.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TiO & TiO2 in VY CMa, band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Spectral setup for VY CMa in band 6 aiming to resolve multiple lines of TiO and TiO2 and detect lines of their isotopolgues. Single pointing.
VY CMa's coordinates (continuum peak) and proper motions from Zhang et al. 2012.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Lines of TiO2 are the weakest features to be observed at full resolution and determine the technical requirements of this SG. Most of the TiO2 lines were observed with PdBI in 2012/2013 (Kaminski et al. 2013). Their typical peak fluxes and line widths are F~50 mJy and FWHM~50 km/s, while the size of the TiO2 emission is FWHM=0.4". The last fugure was also measured in ALMA SV data for VY CMa as the extend of the 50% isophote of the TiO2 emission (Fig. 2 in Sci. Just.).
The peak flux of TiO2 lines per 0.14" beam is then 7 mJy. We wish to observe these lines at a 5-sigma level and therefore request rms of 1.4 mJy. The OT indicates this can be achieved in 1.3 h of total time.
At this sensitivity, the S/N of the TiO peak is expected to be >30 owing to higher peak flux (80 mK in PdBI data) and more compact emission (we estimate it is going to be 0.3") than of TiO2. We note that at such high S/N, spatial information on emission region smaller that the synthesised beam can be obtained. The S/N for profile-integrated emission of TiO2 is then ~30 allowing to detect the 10 times weaker isotopologues at 3-sigma level. After integration of the signal over the entire source, the statistical significance will be ~6 times better and even the 14 times weaker isotopologues of TiO and TiO2 can be identified.
VY CMa's continuum is strong and even after being resolved will produce sufficient S/N for our studies. The peak flux in the PdBI observations at 222 GHz, which did not resolve the source, was 0.22 Jy. Our SMA observation indicate the continuum source size of 0.3"x0.5", giving peak flux of 31 mJy per 0.15" beam of ALMA. At the sensitivity required for line observations we should get continuum images with superior S/N of 1800.

The setup was carefully chosen to cover 2 lines (J=7-6) of the TiO triplet (Eu of 41 & 181 K) and at least 6 lines of TiO2 with Eu from 25 to much over 1000 K (cf. Fig. 1). One remaining correlator unit is set to cover lines of PO and KCl and isotopomeric lines of TiO2. To maximise the number of covered species of our interest here, we need broadest possible covarage the corrlator offers.
Owing to very complex nature of the ourflow of VY CMa, the line profiles have substructure with components as narrow as 3 km/s, fully justifung the requested spectral resolution.

Although the full profiless are relatively broad in VY CMa, they contain substructure which can be resolved only at the resolution of 1.6 km/s or better. The current value is already a compromise after spectral smoothing. The data rate 12.21 MB/s only slighty exceeds the limit of 12 MB/s.

This SG aims to resolve emission of multiple unblended lines of TiO and TiO2 in VY CMa in band 6 at a resolution of 0.15". From PdBI observations and ALMA SV data it is known that the emission regions are smaller than FWHM~0.4 arcsec. Extended configuration of the array is therefore absolutely necessary to resolve the source, especially in TiO (see Science Justification). Although lines of much more extended emission (>>1.0") of other species will be covered by this correlator setup, we do not request a compact configuration, as those species are beyond our science scope. Also, the largest scales of the TiO2 emission reach 1" (see Fig. 2 in Sci. Just.) so higher angular resolutions are not desired here. The C36-6 configuration of Cycle 3 is the most optimal one.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Although dust plays a vital role in many astrochemical processes, its formation around dying stars remains elusive. In particular, it is not understood how inorganic (non-carbonaceous) stardust is produced. Current nucleation theories predict that the first clusters (seeds) are formed from refractory oxides of Ti and Al, but until very recently these species had not been observed. We propose observations in which ALMA will spatially resolve the emission of TiO, TiO2, and AlO - the three most important gas-phase species preceding the formation of seeds. The proposed observations will provide a direct view of the dust nucleation process in oxygen-rich stars. We will observe two objects in which these three metal oxides have been detected: the red supergiant VY CMa and the AGB star Mira, which are prototypes of high- and low-mass stars at the end stages of their evolution. In 7.5 h of total time, we will not only address the urgent questions about dust nucleation, but also shed more light on the mass-loss mechanism in late-type stars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00156.S - Dust nucleation in oxygen-rich envelopes of two evolved stars, VY CMa & Mira - PI: T. Kaminski (grade B)
